information:
Post Malone has received five nominations for the 60th Academy of Country Music (ACM) Awards, scheduled for May 8, 2025. His nominations include Album of the Year for "F-1 Trillion," and three nominations for his collaboration with Morgan Wallen, "I Had Some Help." He is not nominated for the top category, Entertainer of the Year. Key competitors include first-time nominee Ella Langley, who leads with eight nominations. Other heavily nominated artists are Morgan Wallen and Lainey Wilson with seven nominations each, and Chris Stapleton with six nominations.

The reception for cross-genre artists at country music award shows has been mixed historically. Favorable precedents include Beyoncé winning a CMA Award for a collaboration with The Chicks, and Justin Timberlake winning a CMA with Chris Stapleton. Lil Nas X also won CMA Awards for "Old Town Road." However, many artists crossing over face resistance from traditional voters, and the Album of the Year award typically goes to established country artists. Post Malone himself has a history of receiving numerous Grammy nominations without winning; at the 2025 Grammy Awards, he was nominated for eight awards and lost all of them, bringing his career total to 18 nominations without a win.

Post Malone has recently made high-profile moves into the country music scene. His country album, "F-1 Trillion," has had strong commercial performance. He has engaged in collaborations with established country stars such as Morgan Wallen, Luke Combs, Blake Shelton, and Jelly Roll. His recent performance at the Coachella festival featured a country-focused set and guest appearances from Jelly Roll and Ed Sheeran. However, this performance received a mixed reception from viewers and critics.

forecast.status_quo_outcome: No — traditional country artists and incumbents win, and Malone is shut out despite multiple nominations.
forecast.no_outcome_scenario: Voters coalesce around Lainey Wilson, Chris Stapleton, Morgan Wallen solo work, or other core-country entries. “I Had Some Help” gets edged in Single/Song/Music Event by a more traditional pick, and Album of the Year goes to an established country act. If Malone isn’t a credited songwriter, even a Song win wouldn’t give him a trophy, further narrowing his paths.
forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: “I Had Some Help” wins Music Event or Single of the Year (awards that credit the performing artist), or its video wins Video of the Year. A narrower path is an Album upset for F-1 Trillion if industry momentum swings toward recognizing his successful country crossover.
forecast.rationale:
Today is 2025-04-22; the ACM Awards are May 8. Post Malone reportedly has multiple nominations (background says four; assistant report says five, including Album of the Year for F-1 Trillion and three for the Morgan Wallen collaboration “I Had Some Help”). The core question is whether at least one of these categories breaks his way.

Positives for a Yes: He has several at-bats, and “I Had Some Help” was a blockbuster commercial hit with Morgan Wallen, who is very strong with ACM voters. Categories like Music Event and Single often reward big, mainstream moments, and Music Event explicitly credits all performing artists, giving Malone a clean path to an individual win. Multiple nominations materially increase his chance of securing at least one trophy even if Album is a long shot.

Negatives for a No: Cross-genre entrants face headwinds with country award voters, especially in album and songwriter-focused categories. The field is deep (Lainey Wilson, Chris Stapleton, Morgan Wallen, etc.), and the ACMs often favor core-country credibility. Malone’s recent high-profile awards shutouts (e.g., 0-for-8 at the 2025 Grammys) signal some industry reluctance to reward him. If he is not a credited songwriter on “I Had Some Help,” he would not receive the Song of the Year trophy even if the song wins, trimming a pathway. Results across categories are correlated—if voters lean traditional, Malone can easily go 0-for.

Why not higher: Strong, traditional competitors; potential crossover skepticism; correlated downside risk across categories; uncertainty about whether he receives credit in Song of the Year. Why not lower: Sheer commercial dominance of “I Had Some Help,” the Morgan Wallen co-sign, and multiple nominations that create several viable routes (especially Music Event/Single/Video) to at least one win.

What would move me up: Clear industry chatter or predictive coverage indicating “I Had Some Help” is frontrunner for Music Event/Single; confirmation Malone is a credited songwriter (expanding his Song path); signs of ACM voters rewarding crossover success this cycle. What would move me down: Reports of a traditionalist tilt in final-round voting; confirmation he lacks songwriter credit; stronger-than-expected consensus forming around competitors in the overlapping categories (e.g., a sweep narrative for Lainey Wilson/Stapleton) or eligibility/credit quirks limiting his trophy eligibility.

prompt:
You are a professional forecaster interviewing for a job.

Your interview question is:
Will Post Malone win an award at the 60th Academy of Country Music Awards?

Question background:
The awards are scheduled to be held on May 8, 2025. Malone has 4 nominations.


This question's outcome will be determined by the specific criteria below. These criteria have not yet been satisfied:
This question resolves as **Yes** if Post Malone wins an award at the [60th Academy of Country Music Awards](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/60th_Academy_of_Country_Music_Awards).




Your research assistant's report says:
Post Malone has received five nominations for the 60th Academy of Country Music (ACM) Awards, scheduled for May 8, 2025. His nominations include Album of the Year for "F-1 Trillion," and three nominations for his collaboration with Morgan Wallen, "I Had Some Help." He is not nominated for the top category, Entertainer of the Year. Key competitors include first-time nominee Ella Langley, who leads with eight nominations. Other heavily nominated artists are Morgan Wallen and Lainey Wilson with seven nominations each, and Chris Stapleton with six nominations.

The reception for cross-genre artists at country music award shows has been mixed historically. Favorable precedents include Beyoncé winning a CMA Award for a collaboration with The Chicks, and Justin Timberlake winning a CMA with Chris Stapleton. Lil Nas X also won CMA Awards for "Old Town Road." However, many artists crossing over face resistance from traditional voters, and the Album of the Year award typically goes to established country artists. Post Malone himself has a history of receiving numerous Grammy nominations without winning; at the 2025 Grammy Awards, he was nominated for eight awards and lost all of them, bringing his career total to 18 nominations without a win.

Post Malone has recently made high-profile moves into the country music scene. His country album, "F-1 Trillion," has had strong commercial performance. He has engaged in collaborations with established country stars such as Morgan Wallen, Luke Combs, Blake Shelton, and Jelly Roll. His recent performance at the Coachella festival featured a country-focused set and guest appearances from Jelly Roll and Ed Sheeran. However, this performance received a mixed reception from viewers and critics.

Today is 2025-04-22.

Before answering you think:
(a) The time left until the outcome to the question is known.
(b) The status quo outcome if nothing changed.
(c) A brief description of a scenario that results in a No outcome.
(d) A brief description of a scenario that results in a Yes outcome.
(e) You write your rationale remembering that good forecasters put extra weight on the status quo outcome since the world changes slowly most of the time. Explain your reasoning and the evidence behind your forecast in detail. Summarise information your received from your research assistant that influences your forecast (if any). Explain why your forecast is not higher, and why it is not lower. Outline what would need to be true for you to update your forecast in either direction.
(f) The last thing you write is your final probabilistic forecast as a number between 0 and 100.

# OUTPUT SCHEMA
{
    "time_left_until_outcome_known": "string",
    "status_quo_outcome": "string",
    "no_outcome_scenario": "string",
    "yes_outcome_scenario": "string",
    "rationale": "string",
    "probability": "number" (0-100)
}
